pros: Supportive, Fun and Meaningful Work.
cons: I can’t think of anything to change.

review_title: They do NOT care about their nurses
pros: My team of cm's were amazing
cons: They treat their nurses awful. The "DON" doesn't even work. A keyboard warrior, if you will. All she does is send out emails about what we don't do and should do. Never acknowledged the nurses for doing all the real leg work. Everyone gets a stimulus for direct care work EXCEPT the nurses. Their lead nurses don't lead anything, just call in all the time and sit around and put everyone on your schedule while they sleep in their offices. When extra help is needed and it's their "flex" day - they would never think about coming in to help. Isn't that what a leader does? Always short staffed because they're bullies and drive people out of there. I certainly wouldn't waste my time as a nurse. Or any employee. Their cm's with a college degree make less than what McDonald's employees make and they're just too young to leave. They're scared of the backlash from this place. They'll get there. Far too many places that will value you out there. And that will pay you - because again - this place doesn't. They profit so much and pay their staff pennies. HR is all about screwing you to fatten their pockets and they expect the world from their staff and give nothing, but "pins" for your hard work.

pros: Best part of the position is working with the children and families. A bit challenging with productivity requirements but never a dull moment!
cons: Productivity expectations are at times unrealistic. Company went through many changes and lost many employees all at once. Money focused rather than quality.

review_title: Do NOT work for Southwest Network!
pros: There is absolutely NO reason I would recommend working at Southwest Network.
cons:
The culture at Southwest Network is so horrible!  Management does not care about employees.  The environment is one of fear.  It is not a safe place to make a mistake, because if you do you will be blacklisted as a “bad” employee for the rest of your time here.  The focus is only about what you do wrong and not what they do well.  Amy is the worst CEO.  She comes to the clinics very infrequently and when she does she sits in one spot and doesn’t really interact with employees. She’s extremely unapproachable.  Isn’t the CEO supposed to set the example?  Other managers act the same.  All they care about is productivity and not member care.  Even if you are legit sick, you get in trouble for being out!

I will be leaving as soon as I get a new job!

review_title: They Make Promises they don't/can't keep
pros:
Helping people who cannot help themselves
Non-profit qualifies for student loan forgiveness
They pay decently.
You learn by doing and making mistakes since no one is really willing to teach you what matters.
cons:
I enjoyed my time working here and helping members. I always exceeded my units week over week, and I was never reprimanded. This is not a review out of anger or animosity. This is a review based on personal experience out of hope those in a position to improve the company culture and morale do so before it is too late. SWN is one of the best organizations when it comes to providing care for members, but their support for employees leaves so much to be desired. They are all about making money and it that means overloading Case Managers with 60, 70, 80 member supportive case loads then that is what they will do. Their turnover is high because they burn out their staff within a year. 
No support. The majority of Clinical Managers are super unhelpful. 
A lot of promises without actual delivery
They say whatever they have to to get you in the door then NOTHING
CEO Amy Henning literally screams at people working in admin (extremely unprofessional) 
They cancel employee appreciation activities and blame small sanctions ($200,000) but NEVER tell anyone about the nearly $2million they earned in a single quarter from a targeted investment grant that was only made possible by the hard work of those employees who are left feeling unappreciated when the events are canceled.

review_title: Productivity is awful and management can be challenging
pros: Team was great. Helping the members was something i was passionate about.
cons: Productivity seemed like was more important than anything else. Management was not willing to listen to new ideas or feedback. Some of my colleagues were written up for not meeting productivity when they were sick or had an emergency which was ridiculous.

job_title: Behavioral Case Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great clients and great population to work with
cons: Poor management, work life balance not good due to long hours and emergency events

pros: some of the people you work with are cool

review_title: Just what you think it is
pros: Decent opportunity for professional development
cons: Its degrading to have helping interactions with other individuals only be seen as productive if you can bill insurance.

pros: Good staff team, leadership, great experience
cons: Little pay, short staffed, high caseload

pros: Vacation, flexibility, relaxed office setting.
cons: Pay, little help from upper management on complicated cases. Applied and interviewed for various roles, told I interviewed well, never received any promotion.

pros: I enjoy my job and my work with youth.

cons: Long wait between annual compensation

review_title: Would not recommend working for this company
pros: A good place to apply/work if you are young and inexperienced. They will hire people who have never had a real job before.
cons: Most of the staff is very young and you will be considered "old" if you are over the age of 28. The turnover rate is crazy, and most people do not make it to one year (look at Jobing and Careerbuilder at how many ads they post in a month). The turnover issues stem from the low pay (around $14 an hr for a Case Manager), the insane amount of documentation/units required each week, and the lack of advancement opportunities within the company. Additionally, some of the management team are not qualified to be in management and happened to land in those positions due to simply being there for longer than 6 months.

review_title: NEVER WORK HERE, YOU'LL BE SORRY!
pros: members are great to work with, most co-workers are fantastic. You can flex time and arrange your own schedule.
cons: Administration and Clinical Directors DO NOT CARE ABOUT EMPLOYEES! You are given very ridiculous expectations and if you aren't making the clinic money by billing for unnecessary face to face,  home visits, phone calls,..etc.. then they put you on documented coaching. Youget a supervision every week to calculate how much money you made them for that week. If you speak up about wrong doing they find a reason to put you on corrective action. The clinics are scrambling to get units which almost  everyone has to have at least 100 per week, they are years behind on assessments, service plans.. everything and they speak very badly about their members especially the lazy clinical directors that sit in their offices all day eating, shopping online, and collecting a check.  Members do not get the care they need and deserve.

pros: Salary over industry par.  Leadership a constant source of amusement.
cons: Inept management that provides absolutely *zero* support to staff, you will be assigned the highest-needs of adult SMI patients (most of them a half-step from qualifying for an ACT team) whom you are expected to shuttle about the community including transporting to hospitals every time they cry "suicide," while administration barks about not hitting your numbers (here's a hint: it doesn't happen), corporate leadership botched things so bad they lost THREE CLINICS as a result (seriously, how was the entire executive board not replaced as a result?), my clinic had two clinical directors (why, I do not know) of which one was not licensed in the state of Arizona (how, I do not know).  You will go absolutely nowhere beyond Rehab Specialist or Clinical Coordinator with this company.

pros:
Great co workers
Loved the families I worked with 
Flexible schedule (can work from home or out in community) 
Decent pay but not worth the stress
cons:
Driving ALL over Phoenix, Peoria, Avondale, etc. when my site was Chandler. 
Their focus is "productivity" or "unit expectations" which impacts quality of care. 
You'll be terminated/written up for not meeting your expectation 
No workspace- you have to share desks and cubicle areas. 
Training is good but when you get to your site it's completely different than what's taught in training. 
High turnover--- when someone quits you'll get the cases even if they are from a different site 
They pretty much force you to use collaborative documentation which takes away the engagement and rapport building with families

pros: If you want a diverse environment and are willing to work hard to fulfill your impact on others, this is the place to put your talents to good use. Excellent mix of new and seasoned talent all working toward providing quality behavioral healthcare services.
cons: Challenges in behavioral healthcare are universal throughout the industry, not just here at SWN. At times it may seem management doesn't "have your back" or that your efforts go unnoticed. Focus on what you bring to the table and share those strengths with others and the rough times will pass, not to mention make you stronger

pros: To help the mentally ill or yo give a person the chance to feel success. Never the same from one day to the next. Half a day at your desk and the other half driving to meet clients.
cons: No much advance unless someone leaves. Upper management can learn to have people skills. Some employees are protected because of the disability act even if they sleep on the job.

pros: I can honestly say I loved working at SWN. Many of the people there really care about the members. The team worked hard to try to help each other. The members were sometimes difficult but overall it was an enjoyable to work with them.  I would still be there if I could.
cons: The issues with the company are not with the individual clinics. The problem is the unrealistic expectations that are put onto the staff. There is no way a person can put in their units when they are out in the field all day and when they get back they still have to answer phone calls and meet with members that are at the clinic. I understand that this is an expectation that has been put on SWN by the RHBA.  The RHBA must change its ideas on what is most important. Money or the health of the members. However the upper management must understand that the staff are just human.  When my CD and RD let me go it was not because I wasn't a good CM. They even told me this.. It was due to the fact that I cared more for my members than getting my productivity in.  They did not have a choice but had to let me go. This left my team short and now not only having to deal with their members but also mine. Upper management needs to come and spend a week as a CM doing the same work in the same time frame and then state that getting the productivity is possible. I got tired of hearing that others were able to get their units in.  The ones that I know did never went out in the field. They did not meet with members that much. They a couple of minutes on the phone and then were able to bill a unit even if the call was only a minute long.  It is easy if you spend eight hours and only have to make 20 phone calls. Those of us who care and went the extra mile either quit before they are fired or are fired.

pros: Helping clients in recovery to stay safe and maintain a stable living environment and overall health. Clients are also encouraged to learn skills towards their independence as well as towards integrating into the wider community.
cons: Clinic mgmt. is often intense and you can see the power tussle. The top  administrators of this particular clinic manage to hold on to their positions while there is high turnover through the ranks.

review_title: It's as to be expected for a Case Management Position
pros: Pay is better than a typical CM Job, Paid Holidays and all of that good stuff
cons: HIGH STRESS and low integrity on the companies behalf. Always looking for what can be billed for.

review_title: Work Here to get experience in mental health.
pros: You are able to get experience in the mental health field.  You get to help others.  You have autonomy.
cons: The pay does not match the duties and responsibilities.  You have very strict production standards and goals which appear unrealistic.  The pay is not very good for you may work for years and not receive a raise but the price of insurance and benefits increase every year.

review_title: Clinic Staff - How SWN is Building a Mental Health Dynasty on the Backs of the OAs, CMs. Peer Spt and RS's.
pros: Helping severely mentally ill adults to become stable and self-determined.  There are still some great staff who have not resigned or been forced to resign.
cons: Lack of financial compensation (no annual performance raises for 3 years) for the years of experience, the education and the stress that OA, CMs and RSs experience while management gets an 85% increase in pay for the past 3 years (this was in the Phoenix news).  Lack of consideration and respect for those line staff who have served and remain in service 5-15 years.  Lack of adequate compensation for being forced to use personal vehicle in the field while management gets expense and vehicle accounts worth $thousands a year.  Millions in surplus funds being used to build a New Mexico branch of Southwest Network while AZ clinic staff don't have funds to adequately help members.  The attitude/culture with SWN executives and staff trainers that they can get "anybody" to do the work at the clinic level.  High staff turnover due to the management and leadership attitude lack of respect and pay for clinic staff.  Overworked, underpaid, undermined, micromanaged;  and disrespected as professionals.

pros: Good hours to work, near by home. Received an hour for lunch. pleasant employees to work for. Constant training on the job to make you more employable and room for advancement.
cons: The company constantly changes job description and it lacks consistency. The non-profit company seems to lack integrity and respect for their employees hard work. Extreme high turnover rate.

job_title: High Needs Case Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Management at my clinic is amazing. Super supportive team and coworkers. Feel validated and appreciated by management. I get to work with an array of people and help youth in their recovery.
cons: High standards are admirable, but really add slot of pressure and limit ability to balance life and job. No over time and minimal opportunity for advancement since management sticks around.

pros: I enjoy working with my team. we all work very well together.
cons: extremely large case loads. Since we can not turn down any clients, we end up case managing so many clients and the care is poor as a result. High turnover rate for case managers.  I personally am not a fan of the upper mgmt. no "perks" to working at southwest network. No raises.

job_title: Not Gonna Say in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Upward mobility opportunities; promote from within; supported by my management; I get to be a part of improvement projects; they look for feedback from employees; I love working with people to help them grow and improve their lives
cons: Not always enough staff to do the job to the quality it could be

job_title: High Needs Case Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Wonderful leadership team. Positive and supportive work environment. Opportunities for growth are present as long as you are meeting your goals.
cons: Not ver many cons other than assignments are not always within your area even though we have several offices. I work at the central office and have cases all over the valley.

job_title: Case Manager, MSW in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Helping people
Working with clinical team
Working as a team member
cons: Letting clients know they have the right to make their won decisions . As a Case Manager I will continue to assist the client in making the right choice.
